words: Susie doktor ast va moalem ast
gloss: Susie doctor be.pres.3sg CONN teacher be.pres.3sg
translation: Susie is a doctor and she is a teacher.
comment: “va” is pronounced as “o” in social contexts; “ast” is usually pronounced as “e”

words: Paul television mi-bin- ∅ -ad va pirhan-esh ro otu mi-kon- ∅ -ad
gloss: Paul TV impf-see-pres-3sg CONN shirt-her/his acc iron impf-do-pres-3sg
translation: Paul is watching TV and he is ironing his shirts.

words: Susie doktor ast amma faghir ast
gloss: Susie doctor be.pres.3sg CONN poor be.pres.3sg
translation: Susie is a doctor but she is poor.
comment: “amma” might be a loan from Arabic (same in Hausa?); no difference perceived between “amma” and “vali”

words: Susie doktor ast vali faghir ast
gloss: Susie doctor be.pres.3sg CONN poor be.pres.3sg
translation: Susie is a doctor but she is poor.
comment: “amma” might be a loan from Arabic (same in Hausa?); no difference perceived between “amma” and “vali”

words: Jen bastani xar-id amma be ye qharibe dad-esh
gloss: Jen ice-cream buy-pfv.past.3sg but to a stranger give.pfv.past.3sg-it
translation: Jen bought ice cream but she bought it for a stranger.

words: Jen bastani xar-id vali be ye qharibe dad-esh
gloss: Jen ice-cream buy-pfv.past.3sg but to a stranger give.pfv.past.3sg-it
translation: Jen bought ice cream but she bought it for a stranger.

words: Paul doktor ni-st balke monshi ast
gloss: Paul doctor neg-be.pres.3sg CONN receptionist be.pres.3sg
translation: Paul is not a doctor but he is a receptionist.
comment: the more natural way to say it would be without “balke”

words: Paul doktor ni-st monshi ast
gloss: Paul doctor neg-be.pres.3sg receptionist be.pres.3sg
translation: Paul is not a doctor but he is a receptionist.
comment: the more natural way to say it would be without “balke”

words: Jen bastani na-xar-id balke shokolat xar-id
gloss: Jen ice-cream neg-buy-pfv.past.3sg but chocolate buy-pfv.past.3sg
translation: Jen didn’t buy ice cream but she bought chocolate.
comment: with “balke” it sounds very formal; “Be-ja” ~ “instead of”

words: Jen bastani na-xar-id be-ja-sh shokolat xar-id
gloss: Jen ice-cream neg-buy-pfv.past.3sg to-place-it chocolate buy-pfv.past.3sg
translation: Jen didn’t buy ice cream but she bought chocolate.
comment: with “balke” it sounds very formal; “Be-ja” ~ “instead of”

words: Jen bastani na-xar-id shokolat xar-id
gloss: Jen ice-cream neg-buy-pfv.past.3sg chocolate buy-pfv.past.3sg
translation: Jen didn’t buy ice cream but she bought chocolate.

words: Javab-e soal ya A ast ya B ast
gloss: answer-EZ question CONN A be.pres.3sg CONN B be.pres.3sg
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: “EZ” stands for “ezafe” (a nominal linker); a longer version with full conjuncts would sound weird

words: Javab-e soal ya A ast ya B
gloss: answer-EZ question CONN A be.pres.3sg CONN B
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: “EZ” stands for “ezafe” (a nominal linker); a longer version with full conjuncts would sound weird

words: Javab-e soal ya A ast va ya B ast
gloss: answer-EZ question or A be.pres.3sg and or B be.pres.3sg
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: “EZ” stands for “ezafe” (a nominal linker)

words: Javab-e soal ya A ast va ya B
gloss: answer-EZ question or A be.pres.3sg and or B
translation: (Either) the answer to the question is A or the answer to the question is B.
comment: “EZ” stands for “ezafe” (a nominal linker)

words: Ya Paul doktor ast ya John doktor ast
gloss: CONN Paul doctor be.pres.3sg CONN John doctor be.pres.3sg
translation: (Either) Paul is a doctor or John is a doctor.
comment: “va” is not good here

words: Ya Paul doktor ast ya John
gloss: CONN Paul doctor be.pres.3sg CONN John
translation: (Either) Paul is a doctor or John is a doctor.
comment: “va” is not good here

words: Gushi-m ro ya sar-e kar ja gozasht-am ya tu-ye rah oftade ast
gloss: Phone-my acc CONN head-ez work place put.pfv.past-1sg CONN in-ez way drop.pst.ptcp be.pres.3sg
translation: I left my phone at work or I dropped it on my way home.
comment: “ya” could also be sentence-initial here

words: John ya doktor ast ya nevisande ast
gloss: John CONN doctor be.pres.3sg CONN writer be.pres.3sg
translation: John is a doctor or he is a writer.
comment: wouldn’t put “ya” at the beginning here… sentence-initial “ya” sounds exclusive

words: John ya doktor ast ya nevisande ast shayad ham har do
gloss: John CONN doctor be.pres.3sg CONN writer be.pres.3sg maybe also each two
translation: John is a doctor or he is a writer (maybe both).

words: Gushi-t ro sar-e kar ja gozasht-i ya tu-ye otubus ja gozasht-i?
gloss: Mobile-your acc head-ez work place put.pfv.past-2sg CONN in-ez bus place put.pfv.past-2sg
translation: Did you leave your phone at work or did you leave it on the bus?
comment: only one “ya” here

words: Forushgah-e A in berand ro dar- ∅ -ad ya forushgah-e B?
gloss: Shop-ez A this brand acc have-pres-3sg CONN Shop-ez B
translation: Would Shop A sell this brand or would Shop B sell this brand?

words: Paul na doktor ast na parastar ast
gloss: Paul CONN doctor be.pres.3sg CONN nurse be.pres.3sg
translation: Paul is neither a doctor nor is he a nurse.

words: Mike na pul-e bastani ro dad na bastani ro be xahar-esh dad
gloss: Mike CONN money-ez ice-cream acc give.pfv.past.3sg CONN ice-cream acc to sister-her/his give.pfv.past.3sg
translation: Mike didn’t buy ice cream nor did he give it to his sister.

words: Paul ya mi-tavan- ∅ -ad kapkeik ro bo-xor-ad ya mi-tavan-ad koluche ro bo-xor-ad
gloss: Paul CONN impf-can-pres-3sg cupcake acc impf.sbjv-eat-3sg CONN impf-can-pres-3sg cookie acc impf.sbjv-eat-3sg
translation: Paul can eat a cupcake or he can eat a cookie.
comment: two different imperfective markers in Farsi (“bo” for sbjv); “ya” not so good sentence-initially here because the subject should be in the (sentence-initial) topic position

words: Susie doktor ya davande ni-st
gloss: Susie doctor CONN runner neg-be.pres.3sg
translation: Susie isn’t a doctor or a runner.
comment: grammatical but not great in this context; means she is neither; “na” … “na” - sentence strongly preferred

words: Susie ya doktor ni-st ya davande ni-st
gloss: Susie CONN doctor neg-be.pres.3sg CONN runner neg-be.pres.3sg
translation: S. is either not a doctor or not a runner.

words: Susie ya doktor ni-st ya davande
gloss: Susie CONN doctor neg-be.pres.3sg CONN runner
translation: S. is either not a doctor or not a runner.

words: Susie doktor ast, moalem ast
comment: maybe works as a list, but a bit weird; would need an additive

words: Paul television mi-bin- ∅ -ad, pirhan-esh ro otu mi-kon- ∅ -ad
gloss: Paul TV impf-see-pres-3sg, shirt-her/his acc iron impf-do-pres-3sg
comment: a bit worse than the first juxtaposition example (because of the simultaneity, list reading not salient)

words: Susie doktor ast, faghir ast
gloss: Susie doctor be.pres.3sg poor be.pres.3sg

words: Jen bastani xar-id, be ye qharibe dad-esh
gloss: Jen ice-cream buy-pfv.past.3sg to a stranger give.pfv.past.3sg-it
comment: that’s okay, sounds like a sequence of events

words: Susie doktor ast balke moalem ast
Susie doktor nist balke moalem ast
comment: bejash is bad here too (also in the examples below)

words: Susie doktor ast balke faghir ast
Paul doktor ast balke John doktor ast
Paul doktor nist balke John doktor ast
John doktor ast balke nevisande ast
John doktor nist balke nevisande ast
John doktor ast balke nevisande ast shayad ham har do
John doktor nist balke nevisande ast shayad ham har do
Paul doktor ast balke parastar ast
Paul doktor nist balke parastar ast
Paul doktor ast, John doktor ast
gloss: Paul doctor be.pres.3sg, John doctor be.pres.3sg
comment: That’s fine, but would be much better with an additive

words: Ya Paul doktor ast va ya John doktor ast
Paul doktor ast va ya John doktor ast
Paul doktor ast ya John doktor ast
comment: Only with a certain intonation, this is okay

words: Ya Paul doktor ast ya John doktor ast shayad ham har do
Ya Paul doktor ast va ya John doktor ast shayad ham har do
comment: okay, better than the first sentence, but still seems to suggest that only one disjunct is true

words: Paul doktor ast va ya John doktor ast shayad ham har do
Paul doktor ast ya John doktor ast shayad ham har do
Gushi-m ro sar-e kar ja gozasht-am, tu-ye rah oftade ast
gloss: Phone-my acc head-ez work place put.pfv.past-1sg in-ez way drop.pst.ptcp be.pres.3sg
comment: This is contradictory

words: John doktor ast, nevisande ast
comment: This is in no way a disjunction

words: Gushi-t ro ya sar-e kar ja gozasht-i ya tu-ye otubus ja gozasht-i?
comment: You wouldn’t put 2 “ya”s in a question

words: Gushi-t ro ya sar-e kar ja gozasht-i va ya tu-ye otubus ja gozasht-i?
comment: sounds like weird yes/no question

words: Paul doktor ast, parastar ast.
Paul doktor nist, parastar ast.
Paul ya mi-tavan- ∅ -ad kapkeik ro bo-xor-ad va ya mi-tavan-ad koluche ro bo-xor-ad
Paul ya mi-tavan- ∅ -ad kapkeik ro bo-xor-ad mi-tavan-ad koluche ro bo-xor-ad
Paul mi-tavan- ∅ -ad kapkeik ro bo-xor-ad ya mi-tavan-ad koluche ro bo-xor-ad
comment: you can’t blame Paul if he takes both (FC reading but not exclusive)
